body.p:
Carlisle May 11, 1864
To His Excellency
Gov. Thos. E. Bramblet -

Your Petitioner David Berry states that at the March Term of the Nicholas Circuit in 1859 he was fined by the Court $25. for alledged Comtempt of Court in inducing a witness to leave Court when summoned to attend. and also was fined by the Court $20. at the same Term for failing to attend as a witness himself in a suit pending in the Court, and also by verdict of a Jury he was fined twenty Dollars for Gambling.
He says he was not guilty in the 1st & last named cases & was not wilfully Guilty of the 2d offence.

The facts of the first case are briefly these A Mr. Snapp was a witness in a case against this Petitioner & another but left the Court before the Case was called for trial & when called upon to answer for the Contempt he stated that this Petitioner had induced him to leave, whereupon the Court fined your petitioner $25. though he filed a written affidavit denying the charge & purging the Contempt. The facts in the 2d case are these, He was summoned as a witness in a Case pending in the Court, but did not attend, though he intended to, but being at the time a Constable & very busy was called from Town & detained
The suit was unexpected Called in his absence. As he said before he was not guilty of the Charge in the last case and he cannot account for his run of bad luck in being fined in the Cases-
He says Your Predecessor respited the fines & as your Petitioner thought had remitted them. No steps have been taken till quite lately to Collect them
Now Executives are in the off. Sheriffs hands & pressing for collection.

He states that he is poor & the payment of the Claims above would greatly oppress him. He is now doing services for his Country as an orderly in Co 40th Ky Cavalry Refiment & stationed at Gill Mills in Bath County. He prays that these fines be remitted & will ever pray

Hon Thos. E. Bramblet
Gov. of Ky.
Dear Sir at the Request of Mr. Berry I have written & signed his name to the foregoing Petition

I saw Mr. Berry a few days ago & he authorized me to state substantially the facts
above. Mr. Berry in the Federal service and for this Reason if for no other I think he ought to be released from these old fines that he thought had been remitted. The fines are excessive & ^it is^ unaccountable how they happended to be imposed.
We Concur in recommending the Prayer of the foregoing Petition

John. W. Campbell
James L. Arnold
Mr. Campbell is our Representative & Mr. Arnold is our Circuit Court Clerk.
As Judge may err in inflicting fines for contempt but, I will not err by remitting fines for such offences.
